questions.question_text_1: In which scenario is the average response time for FCFS the same as for SJF?
question_texts: In which scenario is the average response time for FCFS the same as for SJF?

options.option_text: When all jobs have the same length
When jobs arrive in increasing order of length
When jobs arrive in decreasing order of length
When jobs have widely varying lengths

questions.question_text_1: What is the correct sequence of tasks that takes place as part of software interrupt handling?   (i) Execute the software interrupt handler (ii) Save the current CPU state (iii) Invoke the kernel scheduler if needed (iv) Restore the CPU state and resume execution
question_texts: What is the correct sequence of tasks that takes place as part of software interrupt handling?   (i) Execute the software interrupt handler (ii) Save the current CPU state (iii) Invoke the kernel scheduler if needed (iv) Restore the CPU state and resume execution

questions.question_text_1: State True or False SJF scheduling can lead to starvation of longer jobs if shorter jobs keep arriving.
question_texts: State True or False SJF scheduling can lead to starvation of longer jobs if shorter jobs keep arriving.

questions.question_text_1: State True or False SJF can provide a better average response time than FCFS for a set of jobs with varying lengths.
question_texts: State True or False SJF can provide a better average response time than FCFS for a set of jobs with varying lengths.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements about the given processes is correct?
question_texts: Which of the following statements about the given processes is correct?

options.option_text: Process 1 and Process 2 will enter their critical sections simultaneously,leading to race conditions.
Process 1 will always enter its critical section before Process 2.
Process 2 will always enter its critical section before Process 1.
Deadlock can occur if both processes try to enter their critical sectionssimultaneously.

questions.question_text_1: Assume that two processes P3 and P4 are sharing a resource. If P3 is never able to enter its critical section because P4 keeps entering its critical section repeatedly, then which of the following conditions is not satisfied?

questions.question_text_1: Given the hexadecimal view of the first few bytes of different files, identify the executable file (ELF file) from the options below. (Hint: The ASCII value of ’E’ = 69, ’L’ = 76, and ’F’ = 70)
